lens.book_chapters: Part 2: Heuristics and Biases ‚Äî Law of Small Numbers, Anchoring, Availability

elements.name: Monthly-First Search Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Anchoring users on a per-night rate during search causes them to systematically underestimate their monthly commitment, producing sticker shock at checkout.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Every housing platform in the category shows per-night pricing on search cards ‚Äî it has been A/B-tested into every product. Split Lease is the first to show monthly commitment as the primary anchor, matching how users actually think about housing costs.
elements.description: A search result card that leads with the full monthly equivalent ‚Äî the total a guest will pay across all their booked nights in a calendar month ‚Äî in large primary typography. The per-night rate appears below in smaller secondary text as the derived number. For the ghost-roommate model, the card shows the schedule (e.g., '4 nights/week') so the monthly number is legible, not mysterious.

visual_spec.layout: Card with photo on top (16:9 ratio), info panel below. Price block anchors top-right of info panel with monthly total dominant.
visual_spec.color_usage: Monthly price in #1a1a1a (primary text). Per-night in #6b7280 (secondary). Schedule badge in rgb(109,49,194) pill. Card background white.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card visible with monthly price prominent, per-night secondary, schedule badge showing days
interaction_spec.hover: Border transitions to rgb(109, 49, 194), box-shadow elevates to 0 4px 8px rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.15), translateY(-2px)
interaction_spec.responsive: Full width on mobile, 2-col grid at 768px, 3-col at 1024px

copy_spec.micro_copy: What you'll pay in a typical month
do: Show the monthly total as the largest number on the card
Show the schedule (nights per week) so the calculation is legible
Include a small tooltip explaining the math on hover
dont: Do not show per-night as the primary price anywhere in the search flow
Do not show monthly total without showing what nights it covers
Do not make this a toggle ‚Äî monthly-first is the default, always

elements.name: Ghost Roommate Model Explainer
elements.problem_it_solves: Users arrive at listings with an incorrect mental model (hotel, roommate, or sublet), forcing agents to correct this from scratch on every call ‚Äî and causing some users to drop off before a call happens.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor has or can have a ghost-roommate model. Split Lease's structural invention requires explanation ‚Äî but that explanation, done right, is the most compelling reason to choose Split Lease over any standard rental.
elements.description: A 'How Split Lease Works' section that appears prominently on every listing page, before the booking CTA. It uses three illustrated steps with first-person lived-experience copy, a schedule visualization (the week view with days colored by occupant), and a short testimonial from a current ghost roommate. It pre-empts the anxiety points: cleanliness, weekly pack-up, and sharing with a stranger you never meet.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width section with gradient header band, then three horizontal steps, then a schedule visualization strip, then a single guest quote.
visual_spec.color_usage: Section bg off-white. Step cards white with purple-tinted shadow. Schedule days in primary purple (your nights) vs light gray (ghost roommate's nights).

interaction_spec.default_state: Section visible in listing page, schedule strip shows current week by default
interaction_spec.hover: Step cards lift slightly on hover (translateY -1px, shadow deepens)
interaction_spec.click: Schedule strip days can be clicked to see next/prev week
interaction_spec.animation: Steps fade in sequentially on scroll-into-view (stagger 100ms)
interaction_spec.responsive: 3-col horizontal on desktop, single column stacked on mobile

copy_spec.secondary_text: You have the whole apartment to yourself ‚Äî you just share the calendar with one other guest who is never there at the same time.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Your nights are highlighted in purple below. Your ghost roommate's nights are grayed out ‚Äî you two will never overlap.
do: Use 'your nights' and 'their nights' language, never 'tenant A/B'
Show the weekly schedule visually, not as a list of rules
Address the cleanliness concern directly with specific protocol
dont: Do not use legal or lease language in this section
Do not bury this below the bedroom description
Do not make it a collapsible FAQ ‚Äî it must be visible by default

elements.name: Structured Counter-Offer Panel
elements.problem_it_solves: Negotiation is already happening off-platform through agents, informal texts, and host pre-calculations ‚Äî but the platform has no mechanism for it, so value is lost and transparency is absent.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Split Lease is the only platform in the mid-term housing category where both parties can collaboratively set the price. Every competitor inherits the hotel-booking UX of fixed prices ‚Äî Split Lease is the first to say 'you both have real constraints, let's surface them.'
elements.description: A structured negotiation panel that appears as part of the proposal flow, giving guests a single-field counter-offer input and hosts a structured accept/counter/decline response. The panel shows both parties' current proposal, the host's pre-set flexibility range (set during listing creation), and a shared adjustment history visible to both after each round. Maximum two rounds before the platform suggests moving on.

visual_spec.layout: Two-panel card: left panel shows listing summary + host's listed price; right panel shows counter-offer input with slider and numeric field, adjustment history below.
visual_spec.color_usage: Header band primary purple. Host price in text-gray. Guest counter in secondary-purple. Accept button secondary-purple. Decline text-only.

interaction_spec.default_state: Panel shows host listed price and empty counter-offer input with helpful placeholder
interaction_spec.hover: Input highlights with purple border on focus, slider thumb animates
interaction_spec.click: Submit counter shows loading state, then updates panel with host's response in real time (or pending state)
interaction_spec.animation: Panel slides in from bottom of proposal flow, counter-offer submission animates to show 'awaiting host response' state
interaction_spec.responsive: Two columns on desktop, stacked single column on mobile with host price summary collapsible

copy_spec.secondary_text: Chantel has listed this apartment at $95/night. If that doesn't quite work, you can propose a different rate. She'll see your offer and respond within 24 hours.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Both of you have real constraints. This is where you surface them.
do: Frame negotiation as collaborative constraint-surfacing, not haggling
Show the host's price alongside the counter-offer input so both anchors are visible
Limit to two rounds and tell users this upfront
dont: Do not allow free-text negotiation ‚Äî structured number input only
Do not label this 'Haggle' or 'Negotiate price' ‚Äî use 'Make a counter-offer'
Do not show the counter-offer option after acceptance ‚Äî only pre-acceptance

elements.name: Night Rescheduling Widget
elements.problem_it_solves: Guests and hosts currently reschedule nights via SMS outside the platform, resulting in lost rate calculations, no paper trail, and hosts accepting old rates they no longer want to honor.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No mid-term housing platform has any active-stay management tooling. Anyplace's product is transactionally complete at booking. Split Lease is the only platform that is more useful on day 30 of your stay than day 1.
elements.description: A compact rescheduling widget embedded in the Stays Manager page ‚Äî the surface users already visit to see their booked nights. In three taps: select the night to move, select the new night, confirm with the updated rate shown. The host receives a notification and can approve or decline. The widget is faster than a text message by design. Rate recalculation is automatic so hosts never agree to informal terms that hurt them financially.

visual_spec.layout: Inline card within the Stays Manager, anchored below the calendar view. Two date-pickers side by side (from / to), rate impact row, confirm button.

interaction_spec.animation: Widget expands with smooth height animation (0.2s ease-out). Confirmation state shows spinner then success/pending message.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full width on mobile with date pickers stacked, side-by-side on tablet+

dont: Do not allow open-ended date range changes ‚Äî only single night swaps
Do not skip the host approval step for date changes beyond 7 days
Do not require more than 3 taps ‚Äî if it takes longer than a text, users will text

elements.name: Commitment Confidence Screen
elements.problem_it_solves: At the moment of committing $3,000+ to a stranger, both hosts and guests lack the specific trust signals they need ‚Äî producing rituals like confidentiality agreements, physical viewings, and demands to meet in person.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Every competitor shows a generic 'verified' badge and calls it trust. Split Lease shows a contextually-specific bilateral trust screen at the moment of commitment ‚Äî surfacing the exact signals both parties need to feel confident, not just converted.
elements.description: A full-screen interstitial that appears when a guest hits 'Confirm booking' and when a host hits 'Accept proposal.' It is not a legal disclosure ‚Äî it is a designed trust moment. For guests: the host's identity verification, response history, and the agent's name vouching for the arrangement. For hosts: the guest's ID status, income source indicator, and the platform's financial protection terms. Both see the agent's name and photo. The framing is: 'Here is everything you need to feel confident about this match.'

visual_spec.layout: Full-screen overlay with centered card (max-width 480px). Top section: two-party match visual (host avatar + guest avatar with a handshake icon). Middle: two-column trust signals. Bottom: CTA.
visual_spec.color_usage: Trust signal rows use subtle purple-tinted backgrounds. Verified badges in #4B47CE. Agent section in primary-purple tinted background.

interaction_spec.default_state: Modal appears on confirm-booking click, both sides shown simultaneously
interaction_spec.hover: Trust signal rows subtly highlight on hover to indicate detail is available
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a trust signal row expands to show more detail (e.g., 'Government ID verified by Persona')
interaction_spec.animation: Modal entrance: scale from 0.95 to 1.0, opacity 0 to 1, 0.3s ease-out
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-screen on mobile with top-sheet style, centered card on desktop

copy_spec.secondary_text: Before $3,000 changes hands, here's everything you should know about each other.

do: Show the agent's name and photo ‚Äî the human vouching is the most important trust signal
Make verification status specific: 'Government ID verified via Persona' not just 'Verified'
Show the financial protection terms in plain language here, not in a PDF
dont: Do not put this screen before proposal acceptance ‚Äî only at commitment
Do not make it dismissible with a single escape key ‚Äî require active confirmation
Do not show only guest-side trust signals ‚Äî bilateral trust is the signature

elements.name: Review Confidence Indicator
elements.problem_it_solves: Users treat a 4.9 rating on 4 reviews as equivalent to 4.9 on 400 reviews, making $3,000+ decisions on statistically unreliable samples without knowing it.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in the housing category has ever tried to correct for the law of small numbers ‚Äî every product team optimizes social proof to look stronger, not more accurate. Split Lease is the first to say 'we respect your ability to evaluate evidence correctly.'
elements.description: A small inline confidence indicator next to every star rating that shows sample reliability visually. A listing with 4 reviews shows a partially-filled confidence arc with a 'Building confidence' label. A listing with 30+ reviews shows a full arc with 'Well-established.' The visual makes sample size viscerally legible without requiring any statistics knowledge. Hovering shows the exact count and a brief explanation: 'We show confidence levels because small samples can produce extreme ratings in either direction.'

visual_spec.layout: Inline adjacent to star rating: [4.8 ‚òÖ] [confidence arc] [Building confidence ‚Äî 5 reviews]
visual_spec.background: Transparent; confidence arc drawn in SVG
visual_spec.color_usage: Arc fill in secondary-purple, proportional to sample size. Track in #f3f4f6. 'Building' label in text-gray. 'Established' label in secondary-purple.

interaction_spec.default_state: Confidence arc shows at approx. 20% fill for 5 reviews, 60% for 20 reviews, 100% for 50+ reviews
interaction_spec.hover: Tooltip shows: 'This listing has 5 reviews. Small samples can show extreme ratings ‚Äî in either direction. 15+ reviews gives stronger confidence.'
interaction_spec.click: Scrolls to reviews section of listing page
interaction_spec.animation: Arc animates in on page load (draw from 0 to value, 0.6s ease-out)
interaction_spec.responsive: Full on desktop, compact (arc only, no text) on mobile

copy_spec.micro_copy: We show confidence levels because small samples can produce extreme ratings in either direction ‚Äî high or low.
do: Use non-judgmental language: 'building confidence' not 'low reliability'
Explain both directions: extreme results can be positive or negative
Link to the reviews section on click
dont: Do not hide or downgrade the star rating ‚Äî show it alongside, not instead of
Do not use red/warning colors for low confidence ‚Äî neutral gray arc
Do not show the confidence indicator on listings with 50+ reviews ‚Äî full arc is implicit

elements.html_css:
Listing with 5 reviews
4.8 ‚òÖ
Building confidence 5 reviews
This listing has 5 reviews. Small samples can produce extreme ratings in either direction ‚Äî a 4.8 here could reflect 5 lucky placements or genuinely excellent stays. 15+ reviews gives stronger signal.
Why we show confidence levels
Kahneman's research shows small samples produce extreme results more often than large samples. We show you sample size because you deserve to know how much weight a rating carries.
Listing with 18 reviews
4.7 ‚òÖ
Growing confidence 18 reviews
18 reviews gives a reasonable sample. The 4.7 rating is more reliable than a listing with fewer reviews, but the confidence interval is still wider than 50+ reviews.
Listing with 52 reviews
4.6 ‚òÖ
Well established 52 reviews
52 reviews provides strong statistical confidence. The 4.6 rating reliably reflects the typical experience across many stays.

before_after.before: Anyplace (and every platform) displays '4.9 (4 reviews)' in the same visual weight as '4.9 (400 reviews)'. The review count appears in small, low-contrast text and users do not spontaneously discount for sample size.
before_after.after: Split Lease shows a confidence arc next to every rating, scaled proportionally to sample size. 5 reviews shows a 20% arc with 'Building confidence.' 50+ reviews shows a full arc with 'Well established.' The sample reliability is visible at a glance.

implements_principles: Respecting users' ability to evaluate evidence

elements.name: Pricing Transparency Tooltip
elements.problem_it_solves: Even after showing monthly-first pricing, users need to understand how the monthly total was calculated ‚Äî especially for the ghost-roommate model where 4 nights/week √ó 5 weeks requires explaining.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Transparent calculation surfaces reinforces the brand position of radical pricing honesty ‚Äî it is not just a number, it is a number with a legible derivation.
elements.description: A small interactive tooltip on every monthly price shown that, on hover or tap, expands to reveal the full calculation: nightly rate √ó nights per week √ó average weeks in a month. For the ghost-roommate model, it shows the schedule visually alongside the math. The tooltip also shows how this compares to a standard full-time rental, so users understand the value proposition of the part-time model intuitively.

visual_spec.layout: Inline underline-dotted on the monthly price, tooltip appears above on hover with calculation table.
visual_spec.color_usage: Tooltip in primary purple for maximum contrast and authority. Divider line rgba(255,255,255,0.2).

interaction_spec.default_state: Monthly price has a subtle dotted underline indicating it is interactive
interaction_spec.hover: Tooltip appears above price, calculation shown as table
interaction_spec.click: On mobile, tap toggles tooltip visible/hidden
interaction_spec.responsive: Tooltip appears below on mobile to avoid viewport clipping

do: Show the derivation as a visual equation, not prose
Include a comparison to 'full-time equivalent' so the value is obvious
Use the guest's actual schedule, not a generic example
dont: Do not make the tooltip feel like a legal disclosure
Do not show per-night as the dominant number even in the tooltip
Do not omit the comparison ‚Äî it is the value proposition made legible
